title: What would the metric system have looked like if it was based on 16 instead of 10? Would it be more or less logical? Would it make a difference? - Quora

response.answer_text: It would depend on whether you chose to do that while using base 16 arithmetic. The reason metric is based on 10 is because the number system we use is also based on 10, so conversions between different sized units are very simple–just shift a decimal. If we used base 16 for our regular arithmetic, a base 16 metric would be equally easy to use, but if we used base 16 metric in base 10 arithmetic (or vice versa) it would be a bit tricky.

We already have a base16 numbering system, it’s called hexadecimal and it uses the numbers 0–9 and the letters A-F… hexadecimal numbers look like this:  It’s a lot less intuitive… you can’t just move decimal points around to change values the way you can with decimal. It’s also a lot harder to count in.
